1:48 - Yes. Yes I do. In 8th grade I took a very novel and wonderful class that I still don't remember the name of. But the class was made up of various "pods" focused on different career paths, from computer animation to civil engineering to aviation (those were the 3 I chose). The instruction was done via laserdisc, with a video teaching and demonstrating various principles, followed by an interactive application of those principles - designing and building a balsa wood bridge, for example. The instructor would mostly walk around the classroom and help students with technical problems or missing instructional materials.

The class was incredible and gave students an opportunity to CHOOSE what they wanted to learn and to explore a multitude of different practical skill paths that they could then pursue through their high school education. While I learned some cool things about metallurgy in that class that have stuck with me, the real value in the class was the broad exposure to many different disciplines. That education revolution happened.

Does the middle school I went to still have that class? No idea. I'd guess not. Institutions tend to resist revolution, and education in America is an institution.

What is actually happening is that the learner is the one who extracts what they want. What people call teaching is merely a repository of knowledge brandishing itself in different levels of assertiveness like that kid in class waving his hand in the air in hopes the teacher will choose them.

The learner comes to the so called "teacher", decides whether or not they would like to learn, actively absorbs the knowledge through various senses, decides whether or not this knowledge is valid and whether the source is credible, challenges it if needed, then commits it to memory.

All modifying teaching methods does, is try to satisfy the desires of the different types of learners like male birds dancing to recieve attention in hopes to have its genetics (biological memory and knowledge) live on.

The current "revolution" in education is home schooling -- which is really not a revolution, as it is historically more the norm than the 30s Dewey model we have been following recently.  With home education you can use all this technology -- from books to YouTube -- in a way that is tailored to the strength of a student, that strengthens the weaknesses of a student, and that diversifies his learning experience.  The job of a teacher, in this case, is not to inspire a student or hold him accountable, but to facilitate self-inspiration and self-accountability, which is what all adults need.  Doing so in a community of like learners is incredibly effective, but those learners also have to be (eventually) intrinsically motivated to pursue their own goals and explore what they are curious about.  Teachers in public schools can see some of the gains of home school by individualizing, by creating a safer social environment free of bullying and ridicule, and by very judicious and sparse use of extrinsic rewards.  This is a minor "revolution", though, as most of the education system is (as the video notes) a tanker that can't really be turned.  Great video, thanks!

That's because learning is self directed. With or without a teacher we are all self taught and no teacher can make someone learn when he or she doesn't want to learn. The power of learning; the ONLY power of learning is emotional in nature. It's called curiosity. Unless this emotion can be invoked, your lessons will fall on deaf ears. This is not nearly so mystical as it might sound. People, like all other animals, need a reason to invest energy in anything (including learning a new trick) - which is something that goes back to the research compiled by Tolman way back in 1932.

You need to give people a beneficial reason to learn (i.e. something that benefits the individual more than it costs to learn and implement). Do this and your students will teach themselves. Fail at this and your students sleep or daydream through your lessons - or, the big one, get sidetracked by the myriad of distractions in the form of ideas attached to what you are teaching which, ultimately, drown out the next point you deliver as the student lingers behind to ponder those ideas instead of moving along with the lesson. Only with the right (i.e. constructive/beneficial) motivation, will students invest themselves in focus on the material delivered in the lesson.

People can learn things from videos - but there are two problems - one is that you can't easily learn something that you don't think you need to know - the other is that you have to know that this "thing" exists in order to want to learn it.   In schools, we try to teach kids things that they don't think they need to know - the ONLY reason to learn (say) calculus is that you're being given a test on calculus at the end of the semester and you need to pass it.   That's a TERRIBLE way to do it.  Good example, my son (in pre-teens) and I were working on writing a simple "platformer" video game together.  He needed to have his character jump - and he couldn't get it to look right.  I realized that although he'd theoretically been taught Newtons Laws of Motion - he'd had no reason to use it or care about it.  But when I pointed out that this is what determines how his game character flew through the air - he hit up Wikipedia, devoured the math and had his game character doing what he wanted.   It actually doesn't matter whether those equations came from a book or lecture notes or a video or...ANYTHING...what mattered was that he suddenly had a "Need To Know".  That's the key here...pushing information into someone's head is a major struggle.   Getting the person to the point where they're hungry for the information isn't.   I had a friend who was a math teacher - he had to teach some basic statistics and frequency charts - and there was an exercise to have the kids roll dice and plot charts and such...urgh.   So he and I sat down one evening with 100 dice and we drilled out all of the "1" spots and dropped molten lead into the holes, filling the holes in and painting them white.   The kids were told nothing - but during the exercise, they started noticing that they were getting a hell of a lot of 6's...the teacher wonders aloud..."surely that can't be right?"...and then the kids were inspired...and they learned how statistics could prove that these dice had been tampered with.

The mistake you've made in this video, Derek, is that you've averaged-together instruction on all subjects and topics, causing differences in effectiveness of various media to be "lost in the noise", then you've falsely asserted that what's true of the over-all picture ("no significant difference") must be true of each individual part (eg, cardiac anatomy and function, to use one of your own examples). This is called "The Fallacy Of Division". (Look it up in Wikipedia.) Different media are better for different subjects and topics! Eg: Books for psychology and philosophy, books + video reenactments for history, live lectures with blackboards and a teacher to answer questions for mathematics, books + teachers for science, books + videos for technology, teachers giving live pronunciation demonstrations and explanations for languages, etc, etc, etc. In short: whatever works, and that is not the same for all subjects and topics.

Furthermore, human teachers are usually not necessary for most people to learn most things, especially at the college level. It's been noted by many that one can gain the equivalent of a $50,000 college education by just reading books in libraries for a total cost of $2 in late fees. No $50,000 debt hovering over one's head for the next 50 years that way. Colleges and universities are for the rich. If you're not rich, libraries and The Internet and home study are a much better option.

And, re "on-screen text interferes with visuals", that is only true for people who haven't learned where the "pause" button is. :-) Those of use who do know where our pause button is, use it relentlessly in YouTube videos such as Ted talks which use a lot of printed text, charts, or graphics in their videos. Or, if the printed text is in the form of "closed captions", and if it just mirrors what's being said in the audio, and if we can understand the audio, we just turn the closed captions off. Not because it "interferes" with anything, but because it's unnecessary and distracting.

And in real life, most teachers don't "inspire students to want to learn", nor do they the opposite, "make students accountable" (well, maybe in military and religious schools, where corporal punishment is still used). No, most teachers in real life just convey information. I've only had about 5 teachers in my entire life who break out of that mold and actually inspired me. As with any other profession, 10% of teachers are great, 10% of teachers are horrible, and the remaining 80% are mediocre.

And, finally, no, "social environments" do not promote learning, they just promote socializing. I realize that as an extrovert, you love social environments. But what you don't seem to realize, Derek, is that half of us are introverts, and we loathe "social situations" and avoid them to the maximum extent possible, and to us they interfere with learning instead of promoting it. About half of the people you meet will be introverts. No, that doesn't mean they're bad people, nor does it mean they have some "disorder"; it just means that they value solitude over company, and would rather read a good book than be jawed-at by an abrasive teacher.

All the "revolutionary" examples you gave were different ways to present information. That is really only a small part of teaching. So, as I see it, is "inspiring, challenging and exciting", though a very important one, nonetheless. I am a part time ski instructor and a big part of any lesson is adapting on the fly to conditions, student's current skills and abilities and, above all else, providing useful, relevant, and comprehensible feedback. The lesson consists more of setting relevant and attainable goals, assessing results of attempts and suggesting tactics to try in attempting to achieve those goals, far more than imparting information about skiing (though that can also be important.

The process of teaching skills, when done well, is an iterative one with lots of feedback. The process of teaching information also needs to have feedback, so that misunderstood or simply missed information can be detected early and corrected before it is needed to further the student's development, at least if it to be truly effective. None of these technologies have any such feedback, including youtube videos, have any such feedback. Now, computer programs could be developed that have such feedback built in (and it works - just consider how many video games there are and how many players achieve competency if not expertise without any "education"). This can also be done with paper media - remember "programmed learning" books? I suspect any true revolution in education will take this form, but I don't see much institutional desire to develop any such programs, outside a very few programs (I believe the NY school board ran an experiment in tailoring programs to the individual students, using multiple educational modes and constant monitoring to adjust if the chosen program was not benefiting the student) and possibly the adult education industry where competition and economics forces don't allow compacency.

The speaker asserts that "what limits learning is what goes on in the students head" - and that the teacher's job is "to guide the social process of learning" - both of which are good statements - but incomplete.

Shouldn't a good teacher have done the hard work of going out and gaining knowledge, life experiences and wisdom? Shouldn't a good teacher cut a course through the thicket of ideas and knowledge to then return and lead his/her students down that familiar path to it's end - a glorious place where they will cut a new path through onward?

It seems to me that there is too much push for teachers to be mere bio-components in 'the next big thing to revolutionise education' - baristas at the the foo-foo corporate global coffee shop of school - when instead, we should be so much more than living-cogs in a blandly unified education machine; we should be unique individuals leading students down unique paths that can only be forged by you, me, real human teachers. Here's what I think regarding specifically lectures: lectures work the way they do because the only way to teach back then was do it live, in real time. Computers made playback and editing possible, so why the hell are we recording a live lecture and then playing it directly back? It's just lazy. A truly educational lecture on a computer should either resemble the style of this video, or at least be scripted so you can condense 1 hour of materials into 10 minutes of high quality content that is both easier to understand and more concise.

One example I can think of is Ian Hubert's animation tutorials. He spends a single minute talking about how to do something, such as how to make cities out of skyscrapers or animate a group of moths. He does something in one minute so clearly and concisely, there is not a second where I feel bored or might lose attention. In the end, I learned more from a one minute video than what might take others 20 minutes to explain without a script or video edits.
The best educational course is one that contains as little live, improv speech as possible and plenty of animations and short, concise descriptions.

Hi man, thanks for the video! I am very interested in education and how the traditional process can be improved. Over my recent university years I have made some observations:
1.) MOOCs are great, but they miss human contact. It is kinda studying alone. I cannot talk about the stuff with classmates as I would normally would. Also if I dont understand something I cannot interrupt the teacher at the moment and ask him to explain something more or to challenge his proposed ideas.
2.) I think we should combine videos/reading for transferring the information and then just be in class to discuss these things or solve some problems - use the classroom for its most valuable things it offer - dialogue, immediacy.
3.) People wanna do courses from scratch. There has been a lot of things done already. Teaching a language? Let people learn the vocabulary with memrise.com. Teaching algorithms? Tell students to watch MIT OCW video about the topic before the class. Dont write your own Linear algebra book, let them use the famous Introduction to LA written by Gilbert Strang.
4.) Education should be about creativity, finding new ways to approach things, experiments, yet, teachers and school are extremely rigid and unwilling to change or modify the system if a new things is proposed.
5.) People should not be told things (such as A^2=B^2+C^2) - people should be given problems and understand why we want to solve it first. How would a worker figure out whether he has a right angle between 2 walls he built (Pythagorean theorem)? Why should I write readable code? Give students task to program something and then another task to modify it and them tell them to modify example well designed code. They will understand that rewriting their ugly code for hours was wasted effort.
6.) I miss learning by doing. Sometimes the best way to learn something is not by studying it in the first place, but by doing that when doing something else. Lets say TEX - teach people it and they might forget. Give them a chance to get bonus points for writing linear algebra HW in TEX starting from simple things and they will appreciate that.
7.) peer reviews are great - do work and then evaluate the same task of someone else (or also your own as well).
8.) I think it has been written at multiple places - when a test or HW is done, people should see the results/correct solution ASAP so they still remember what they have done. Exams are not for evaluation, but also crucial for learning itself. Checking my quiz a week after I wrote it and I have no idea why I have written the things I have.
9.) I think one advantage of classical universities is also that they are complete - they have some well (more or less) defined syllabus and offer a package of courses for a given major.

While video discs, radio, and TV are no longer practical methods as technologies, we are literate about the affordances of their underlying technology, how they work, and the value of live or pre-recorded media can serve as part of a suite of options in a communication toolkit -- even if the exact technology has been replaced.

Second, the author defines the effect of technologies too narrowly. Motion picture film was used as a basis for military training, political propaganda, "mental hygiene", documentary, and artistic expression. Perhaps he thinks that education only refers to "what we do when we learn in traditional classrooms", but that couldn't possibly be what was intended. (Eduction extends far beyond the classroom).

This video is too often dismissive of the effect of each progression of communication technology on how we sense the potential of our presence and how we scan our environment for information.

Last, the author is incorrect about technologies not being inherently superior to certain other forms of communication. Video can demonstrate compressed passage of time, reproduce interpersonal communication, and can be played repeatedly. And on and on. Just look up Kozma's research on the affordances of media in cognitive processing.

Derek, loved the video, but I also think an important element of technology revolutionizing education is the cost factor. Certainly, when the first motion pictures came out, the cost to produce a short clip, let alone one centered around an educational topic, would have been astronomical. The costs would have far outweighed the benefits. This probably held true up until the time when specific topics were covered in video format (in large part through the direct involvement of large production companies and educational channels funded by the government) - i.e. via the good old VHS tapes we used to watch as kids in school. For me, this was Bill Nye The Science Guy videos. However, these videos were more demonstrative rather than diagnostic - so students would watch, but could not engage/get "hands on"/learn by trial-and-error. But given the ubiquity of YouTube and the low cost to entry, the truly transformative aspect is the platform, not necessarily the videos, which provides educators a medium to structure content, and for learners to absorb this content in their own pace (good example - KhanAcademy). Again, key here is structure - there's a progression of learning that takes place with KhanAcademy. With other education channels - like yours, SciShow, VSauce, CGP Grey - the videos are more discovery-based. The topics are more sporadic and the content is geared towards explaining a certain phenomenon. It's more "hey - here's a cool thing we found that we think you'll like to hear about", rather than "hey - here's Biology Lesson #1".  Not trying to argue your points as they are all valid. I'm a retired physicist-engineer. I'm a lifelong learner and I've done industrial design of electronics and taught electronics in the classroom setting to novice would-be technicians. I've mastered countless other physical and mental skills as well, from music to medical technician. I recall when I was four or five wanting to be a scientist when I barely knew what to call it. Everything I saw I remembered and it all looked obvious to me. When I went to school I always seemed to learn everything shown to me first time, and never had to be shown again. This while I saw other kids struggling around me. I noted that while I always believed I could learn anything, and that excited me, that they didn't believe that about themselves, and were consequently uninterested, except to get teachers and parents off their backs. This continued into high school and so on. There were always a small number for whom science was all they ever wanted to do, and the rest who never seemed to know what they wanted to do in life except find a way to keep people in authority from bothering them to learn and find a way to get rich quick so they didn't have to learn anything. Scientists are people who would do science even if they couldn't find a way to be paid for it. They approach everything in life as an experiment and it fascinates them. They can't picture doing without that in their life, even if they had to do it for free. The rest seem to live on the outside of things, and they can't figure out what to do with themselves and try to find happiness with formulaic antidotes to boredom, sports, marriage, family, parties, and other distractions that bored people like me. And if you try to teach them things they can't remember them for more than five minutes. These are the people who are always calling their friends up to "fix" their computer when they screw it up. These are the folks who get gypped by their mechanic because they never bothered to find out how engines work or what is what in gasoline vehicles. They seem quite sad to me, really, they have NO confidence that they can learn, and that lack dates back to before they even went to school. I'm not sure if it comes from the way their parents talked to them, or didn't, or the way they first apprehended the tiniest lessons in the way the world works not long after birth. My impression is that it is a fool's errand to try to teach these folks, they will not learn, they have a mental block against it, and no strategy, no new teaching medium, or any such new method will enable them to believe they can learn. And of course people lose interest in things that totally stymie them. I am beginning to believe this may be inherited, and that it may have something to do with the complement of genes and their behaviors which we inherited from our forebears, and the distribution of some very special genetic features in a small percentage of the population. Whatever it is, it is inherited unevenly throughout the human population, and there appears to be some Gaussian distribution of these abilities in our population genome that will ever prevent many people from achieving that kind of facility with ideas. As an inveterate teacher I hate that thought, but as I grow older it seems more and more to be the obvious reason why we struggle in vain to teach many or most students.
We need to be looking from the inside-out, not the outside-in of the student.

Although I agree with the final message of this video, the representation of current and historical trends in instructional technology research is misinformed, misleading the viewer into thinking that those who study the application of technology to learning are misguided. (I do not necessarily believe this is the author's intent, and an entire field of study is admittedly irreducible to a seven minute video.) Yes, the field engaged in decades of media comparison studies, but only to learn the affects of new types of technology on learning - definitive information we would not have without such studies - not to make bold claims that technology would always revolutionize education (or, rather, "schooling" as is actually depicted). This is simply not a statement that serious researchers in this field make. Such exaggerated predictions tend to emanate from disassociated sources (Edison did not, himself, conduct empirical research on instructional technology integration that I am aware of.). The scholarly field of instructional technology research also is rooted in the foundations of psychology, sociology, and other sciences that embrace the essence of the final point you made in your video. The study of "how" technology can assist with learning is anything but recent as evidenced by no fewer than fifty or sixty years of research on instructional design. Despite, arguably, initial leanings toward strict behaviorism, much of it has responsibly attended to the benefits of social interaction, paying homage to the likes of Vygotsky, Dewey, Du Bois, etc. This video, however, strings together a series of points about research strands not directly related to each other over the historical expanse of the field, painting an overall inaccurate, and certainly incomplete, picture. It has never been correct to assume that technology would "revolutionize" education, and I have never heard a contemporary instructional technology researcher say that he or she thought that it could (with the obvious caveat that no one can fully know what all future technologies may be).

Love this video, but I gotta pick it a bit. Static graphics are certainly better at promoting memorization of processes (thinking of that heart animation and the graphics) because they require the student to animate the pictures in their own heads, thereby reinforcing specific synaptic connections, but before a student can memorize a process, she/he must grasp it first. This is where animations can be necessary. A person cannot imagine processes she/he has not seen/experienced anything like before (think of Piaget's experiment that involves young children learning about liquid volume characteristics in containers, or a child learning the sound of a musical scale). She/he must see it or something like it to intuit it, and then at that point a student could pause to think about it or look at static graphics and recreate the animations in her/his own head to reinforce memorization. It could be considered this way: demonstration first for understanding, and practice afterward for reinforcing (there are many parts to learning, and memorization is one of the most basic parts, if not the most). To sum up my point, I think it is sometimes best for a student to see an animation AND static graphics, in that order. Also, if the animation could be paused/replayed, just as a music teacher could play a passage of music multiple times, more slowly, or even just certain parts of the musical passage, that would be beneficial. I hope this makes sense. If it truly, objectively doesn't, I hope someone corrects the way I'm thinking.

Not to rebuke you, but I want to point out that the ideal learning environment is unattainable. If we're talking about a true revolution, I want to think about how billions of people can reap the benefits of modern knowledge and understanding. We need to start acknowledging that each medium (classroom, private tutor, MOOC, online lecture, etc) has its own inherent limitations in its ability to disseminate information. When we take away the gimmicks, the games, the point systems, the bells and whistles; they only vary in volume, density, speed, and organization. For example, your videos are always about one topic matter. It would be unrealistic and hyperbolic to ask you to upload a video about the entirety of physics. Once we start to have conversations about each medium's time and place, we can start fine tuning them to their appropriate function.

I don't think the revolution will come from any technology, whether it be a book or a holodeck. This line of thinking never bothers to address the learner's agency in their own education. I think the revolution will be a shift in attitudes and practices. I absolutely agree with you that teachers are guides; people who inspire and challenge. But a challenge requires a participant. I imagine a world where people recognize what media they need at what specific moments in their learning, and seek to extract information where ever they can. We would see a different world if systems existed to facilitate individuals mobilizing themselves into a modern education; as opposed to waiting for the revolutionary technology to come along.

As a graduate student in 2001, I was a teaching assistant for an introductory undergraduate biology course, and my students were part of an experiment in scientific education focusing on scientific writing. All of the teaching assistants were provided with a spreadsheet feedback form that we were to provide to each student for their initial and final writing assignments over the semester. For each line item on the form, we were to assign a score on a 3-point rating scale - poor, average, or excellent. The spreadsheet was designed to generate a score based on these ratings, which were weighted by line item, but a student who scored average on every line item would still end up with a score of 50% - a failing grade.

The teaching assistants weren't required to use this score to assign a grade, but I felt it was the most objective way to go about it and would best reflect how I felt the student had performed overall, so I restructured it to a 5-point scale and re-weighted the levels to more closely reflect the A-F grading system the university used, so that a student who scored average on all the items would actually get an average grade. I also tried to make comments where I could to let students know specific things they could have done differently or areas where they could improve, and I always made it clear that they should contact me if they had any questions about the materials. The number one need that I saw was for them to develop good critical thinking skills, and I worked at getting them to develop those skills.

After the semester was over and the results of the experiment were tabulated, I was told that my students had shown the most improvement in their scores of any of the participating lab sections. I've always felt that their performance was a reflection of the level of engagement I tried to encourage in them, and I've always believed that the teacher's most important task is to get students to move beyond rote memorization and to learn to think critically for themselves and make life itself a learning process. Seeing that done universally would truly revolutionize education.

There are a lot of problems with this video. But the fundamental thrust of it seems to be; hasn't happened yet, therefore won't happen in the future.

There's also a danger in citing the learning outcomes provided by the best teachers (those that inspire) and then extrapolating them across the board; given how variable teacher quality (especially at the higher education levels where teaching isn't actually their primary purpose) can be.

Ultimately, there's significant efficacy to packaging up information in a manner that provides for maximal attentive saliency. Yes, if you attend to the text and can visualize what is been said and illustrated, then you achieve what you need to out of the outcome. And yes, making it overly automated can reduce attentive efficacy.

But that doesn't mean we're in an either or situation. Use design to better figure out how to best bring together the ability to provide keen visualizations with keen story telling and attention holding capacity. If that means it has to be overproduced, super interactive, then that's what it has to be. If it means that text and images will suffice, that's great too. But what it really probably means is that... we have a wider selection of information presentation methodologies that will better align with the wide variety of student and student learning types out there.

At the end of the day... in order to actually learn, you need information and attention and the ability to relate that information to other things that you know and understand. This is best achieved through an education tailored for the individual (such that the teacher or some mechanism understands what gaps are in each student's knowledge and understands how it needs to be filled). Unfortunately, it's still cost prohibitive to provide tailored education; but technology can be used in concert to help better tailor the nature of that educational experience. Some parts are fairly repetitive (like information lecturing). Some parts require individualized attention (understanding competencies) - which can be solved indirectly through automated assessment and curriculum trackers (like with the Khan Academy). Some parts require social attention and care to handle the smaller but just as critical issues that technology simply can't solve for yet.

Better teachers is always a great idea. But don't let that blind you to other solutions with potential for extraordinary efficacy. Like using technology to better get you in touch with a wider social network of learning and instruction interested peers.

There are some "new age" schools that are taking a "revolutionary" approach to classroom style learning. If I may tick off (and paraphrase) some of your points:
- Technology by itself will never revolutionize education. It can enhance the experience by bringing more information in more varied forms into the classroom, ultimately appealing to an increasing range of learning styles, but that's about it.
- Anything extraneous needs to be eliminated from a lesson: simply put - remove distractions. I agree! But this concept has to extend beyond unnecessary content in the learning materials. This is where the fundamental changes have to happen. The student for whom the lesson moves too slowly will get bored and turn their attention to other things. Similarly, the student for whom the lesson moves too quickly will eventually stop listening, get bored and turn their attention to other things. These are distractions, i.e. extraneous activities.
- YES teachers in their current incarnation are obsolete...and they have been for about 100 years! Nuff said.

What some of these new schools are doing is decentralized, self-paced learning. Sort of like Khan, but I don't mean to say everyone should just watch YouTube videos at home and expect a well-rounded education. There are very important social aspects to learning as well - especially for younger students. (By the way, nothing against Kahn. I think they are a great learning resource.)

Keeping a student engaged and excited about learning is the real trick, and THAT is the most important thing the teacher can provide. The information they convey is secondary, and can be gotten almost anywhere. The teacher's primary job should be to teach a student how to learn, remove roadblocks, and provide guidance and encouragement.

An excerpt from Teaching As A Subversive Activity by Neil Postman & Charles Weingartner (1969):

"""
What all of us have learned (and how difficult is it to unlearn) is that it is not important that our utterances satisfy the demands of the question (or of reality), but that they satisfy the demands of the classroom environment. Teacher asks. Student answers. Have you ever heard of a student who replied to a question, 'Does anyone know the answer to that question?' or 'I don't understand what I would have to do in order to find an answer', or 'I have been asked that question before and, frankly, I've never understood what it meant?' Such behavior would invariably result in some form of penalty and is, of course, scrupulously avoided, except by 'wise guys'. Thus students learn not to value it. They get the message. And yet few teachers consciously articulate such a message. It is not part of the 'content' of their instruction. No teacher ever said: 'Don't value uncertainty and tentativeness. Don't question questions. Above all, don't think.' The message is communicated quietly, insidiously, relentlessly, and effectively through the structure of the classroom: through the role of the teacher, the role of the student, the rules of their verbal game, the rights that are assigned, the arrangements made for communication, the 'doings' that are praised or censured."

Have you ever heard of a student taking notes on the remarks of another student? Probably not. Because the organization of the classroom makes it clear that what students say is not the 'content' of instruction. Therefore, it will not be included on tests. Therefore, they can ignore it.

Have you ever heard of a student indicating an interest in how a textbook writer arrived at his conclusions? Rarely, we would guess. Most students are unaware that textbooks are written by human beings. Besides, the classroom structure does not suggest that the process of inquiry are of any importance.

Have you ever heard of a student suggesting a more useful definition of something that the teacher has already defined? Or of a student who asked, 'Whose facts are those?' Or of a student who asked, 'What is a fact?' Or of a student who asked, 'Why are we doing this work?'

Now if you reflect on the fact that most classroom environments are managed so that such questions as these will not be asked, you can become very depressed. Consider, for example, where 'knowledge' comes from. It isn't just there in a book waiting for someone to come along and 'learn' it. Knowledge is produced in response to questions. And new knowledge results from the asking of new questions; quite often new questions about old questions. Here is the point: once you have learned to ask questions - relevant and appropriate and substantial questions - you have learned how to learn and no one can keep you from learning whatever you want or need to know. Let us remind you, for a moment, of the process that characterizes school environments: what students are restricted to (solely and even vengefully) is the process of memorizing (partially and temporarily) somebody else's answers to somebody else's questions. It is staggering to consider the implications of this fact. The most important and intellectual ability man has yet developed - the art and science of asking questions - is not taught in school! Moreover, it is not 'taught' in the most devastating way possible: by arranging the environment so that significant question asking is not valued. It is doubtful if you can think of many schools that include question asking, or methods of inquiry, as part of their curriculum. But even if you knew a hundred that did, there would be little cause for celebration unless the classrooms were arranged so that students could do question asking; not talk about it, read about it, be told about it. Asking questions is behavior. If you don't do it, you don't learn it. It really is that simple."""

Your question "how do we use our tools to best promote learning" is profound. We must wonder why experts haven't been asking this question all along. We must also ask the question of why society at large doesn't understand that the role of teachers is to facilitate learning, as you say. I think the answer still lies with the educational bureaucracy.

It's not that bureaucracy is slow to make a change, per se. It would be irresponsible for all classrooms everywhere to make the switch from the present nearly uniform format to a radically different, but still uniform format.

The first harm that bureaus present is that they hinder experimentation and innovation in the classroom. With the presence of federal and state standards requiring certain educational tools or methods, teachers hands are tied. They become unable to meet the individual needs and learning styles of their students. In some cases, they are punished for trying to find better ways to educate kids.

The second harm is that the present system takes power out of the hands of parents and puts it into the hands of professional educators. Since school administrators are paid from the top down, they have every incentive to listen to their supervisors while ignoring parents. Wealthy and middle class students may have some choice because their parents can afford to move to a town with better schools or take the financial hit and pay for private school as well as the taxes that go to public school. However, the poor do not have these luxuries. Poor parents have no bargaining power because they can't afford to move their kids. Parents need the power to choose because the only people who have a direct stake in a child's education other than the child themselves are the parents. This can be effected by total privatization with scholarships or via a voucher system.

New technologies are frequently used as learning aids - however, different pupils/students have different preferred learning styles: one may grasp a topic by listening to a teacher talking, another may grasp it by watching a video or animation, another may grasp it by a textbook. Others may use a combination of all methods and still be confused - so requiring the teacher to break down the information into an easier-to-access format (e.g. simpler language, one sentence at a time). With skills-based courses, another learning style opens up: kinaesthetic (i.e. actually doing it).

A successful teacher blends as many learning styles into their lesson as possible, in order to reach out to as many pupils/students as possible. Informing the pupils/students of the learning objectives and outcomes is also useful - many teachers in the UK (particularly in primary) are encouraged to share WALT / WILF at the start of the lesson: We Are Learning To... / What I'm Looking For.

In addition to catering to the various learning styles, successful teachers also blend in something called differentiation - even when classes are divided into ability/attainment sets, there'll be a wide spread of "intelligence" (for want of a better word) within the group. Some will grasp the concepts instantly, others will need them repeated / broken down, others will need to be taught in smaller groups or even 1:1. Another part of differentiation is coping with the fact different pupils will progress through the task at different rates - so setting extension tasks for those who complete early.

If that wasn't enough, teachers also have to be able to prepare at short notice a written form of the lesson that can be distributed to pupils who aren't in class (e.g. ill, pregnant, on an in-school suspension, excluded).

Ofsted (the UK government's Office for Standards in Education) carry out regular inspections of schools and also like teachers to be able to tell an inspector a pupil's progress both within the lesson and course.

Then once you've been able to cope with that, you throw behaviour and behaviour policies into the mix. Disruptive pupils have to be dealt with inside the classroom - it's no longer acceptable to get them to stand outside the door. A typical behaviour policy has a list of sanctions that start off with verbal warnings, then relocating within the classroom (if possible), then migrating onto lunchtime detention (in the school I taught, practically useless as they stood in the school hall facing the wall for half an hour) and eventually after school detention (only with the consent of the Head of Year), in-school suspension (typically they took their lessons with other suspendees in a spare classroom supervised by teaching assistants - often they'd produce great work in that environment, separated from their peers, but as soon as they were back in the classroom...) and eventually fixed period exclusion.

Secondary schools provide teachers with some "free" periods per week (ostensibly to give them a bit of in-school time for planning, preparation and evaluation), but they're often eaten into by providing cover for absent teachers.

Factor in the extensive amounts of time required to plan and prepare lessons, plus mark all the pupils' work (even for small classes of 20, with up to 6x 50 minute lessons per day, that's an awful lot of work to do after hours!), prepare reports and parents evenings etc. Then there's the pastoral side - if a teacher has a registration group, they have to produce a pastoral report for all those pupils and comment in parents evenings.

Once all the business of teaching is dealt with, there's government policy. The current government visualise 1950s Grammar Schools as utopia so seek to encourage schools to emulate that model. There's an increased emphasis on English, Maths and Science, with arts subjects increasingly sidelined, together with psychology, sociology and media studies (frequently criticised by compliant media sources as not real subjects that don't teach anything useful and their very existance is evidence that education and academia are infested with loony left liberals, who they claim also distribute "prizes for all," refuse to ever label a child a failure and eliminate any form of inter- or intra- class competition [what planet are the media commentators living on?!]). To qualify for entry into the annual League Tables, a GCSE-level subject must have no modules or coursework and be assessed purely by an end-of-course written external examination (whether academic or vocational - since the latter have traditionally been skills-based courses assessed by coursework and/or modules, the courses have been substantially rewritten). Science practicals were only belatedly added to the science specification, but contribute no more than 10% of the mark. The National Curriculum has also been revised, with the History syllabus requiring pupils to be taught in strict chronological order as they progress through school (so 4 year olds will be taught about Ancient Britain [iron age etc.], progressing up to the World Wars by 15-16).

Despite claims to the contrary, the government (and compliant media) like schools to act as exam factories, introducing ever more tests to formally assess a pupil's achievement and progress (there's a short test to assess what they know within a couple of weeks of arriving at school at 4-5, a "phonics check" at age 6 to determine whether they've mastered synthetic phonics [the test even including a handful of made-up words to determine whether pupils are really using phonics to form words or have just memorised a large vocabulary]), Key Stage 1 SATs at 7, Key Stage 2 at 11, Key Stage 3 at 13, GCSEs at 16, 'A' Levels at 18). Ofsted inspections are heavily geared towards "teaching and learning" with little emphasis on ethos / environment / pastoral care, and the annual league tables are based purely on the pupils' achievement. Although there is a "value added" measure which takes a pupil's performance within the first year of school, estimates what GCSE grades they'd get if they progressed at the same rate, and assigned scores above 1,000 if they exceed expectations (interpreted as entirely due to the teacher's input) and scores below if they fall below expectations (interpreted as the teacher's fault); the tables are generally sorted by raw achievement (so you'll typically find academically selective schools at the top of the pile).

A short critique if I may. It seems a little unclear as to what is meant by a 'revolution in education.' The video seems too broad and ambiguous as a result. 

The term revolution generally comes as a response to a fundamental problem(s). Such a problem is not clearly identified. In fact, I'd go as far as saying that the term education itself should be better defined. Derick alludes to the problem when he talks about the turtle programming, whereby 'reasoning' is not being invoked or when he says that the classroom dynamic of a teacher in front of a class of students hasn't changed as a result of technology. But the questions still remain as to what is meant by 'education' and what is that which requires change.

There are plenty of theorists who discuss student learning and its processes, and depending on their background, each theorist provides a different perspective and points to problems in a certain area. For example, a sociologist would perhaps argue that education is not improving because of the flawed structures of educational institutions themselves in relation to the wider institutions of society, or that learning is a cultural phenomenon. A political philosopher would perhaps argue that education is another tool of power put in place to continue subservience in order to keep the hamster wheel turning and is not particularly designed to promote higher thinking. A psychologist may argue that students are subject to environmental stimuli and a lack of improvement in education is a result of such stimuli. Someone with a background in neuroscience may perhaps argue that learning is purely a biological phenomenon and we'd need to understand the brain better before one could clearly say how to improve student learning (if student learning is the issue at hand).

I don't mean to sound like a hypocrite, I acknowledge that these examples are broad and also don't identify the problem nor define the term 'education.' But I only point them out to illustrate the broadness of this topic with regards to academic inquiry. As a student of education, a number of names come to mind such as Skinner, Vygotsky, Erickson, Pyrgot, Bloom.. There are plenty more but they slip my mind at this point, and I may have misspelled their names. These theorists have at least had their work implemented as policy and are standard works to go by if one pursues this field (in Australia). And studies here have shown their work to be quite effective in comparison to past educational structures. And their work does not attempt to 'revolutionise' education. Their work is implemented into the already existing classroom structure. It's the pedagogy that has changed - the teacher-student dynamic is at the heart of the issue. Although this requires the teacher to effectively utilise what they have supposedly learned and according to fellow students, this is much easier said than done.

That's why I think this video is rather unclear. Nonetheless, it provokes questions and thoughts and it's interesting to read the discussions here in the comments.

I'd like to hear your opinion on grading and other forms of student evaluation. I went to a K-8 school without grades, and upon reaching high-school, it seemed strange that of my peers were motivated so much by these weird little letters that started appearing at the tops of our assignments. As I’ve observed both highschool students and younger students, I’ve often wondered if the role grades play in our current system of education could be improved. I don’t believe grades are inherently detrimental to learning, and they seem fairly necessary in a practical way, as they play a necessary role in determining which students can benefit from the limited resources that exist in higher education. However, one of the main issues I have with our current education system is how early teachers and parents assign getting good grades as the primary focus of school. This system implicitly treats learners as lazy and unmotivated, since it assumes that they can only be motivated to learn by arbitrary and superficial “rewards” or measurements of success, rather than intellectual curiosity for what they’re learning about. Because of these “rewards,” I’ve observed countless students begin to lose their original interest in their subjects and turn towards the immediate gratification from school, which is reinforced at home. I’m not just talking about getting golden stars for reading books in Kindergarden—this culture produces elementary-schoolers who work for A’s to please their parents, high-schoolers who work to get into prestigious colleges, and college students who work only for the highest-paying degree. If we deemphasized the rewards and emphasized the learning from an early age, how would our next generation grow up? What could they discover?

I agree that teachers are arbitrators, not educators. I believe we're one step ahead of the problem in this though. In order for education to work, the person being educated has to want to be educated. It doesn't matter how you approach educating them if they will not -- or rather cannot -- apply their attention to learning. If you want to teach students you have to out-perform the other things that are competing for their attention. This is a fundamental rule and it applies to everyone. But go to a college -- even a reputable college -- and look at the majority of the people. If you live in America, you see that they don't want to dedicate their attention to studying or learning, they want to make friends and take snapchats and live the American dream.
A more prominent issue today lies in the types of people that are entering college. Improvement in technology has machines replacing low-skilled workers, and these low-skilled workers are forced to go into college in order to qualify for better jobs or else they remain unemployed. But for most the reason they are low-skilled is because they weren't able to get through school the first time around. When the majority of them fail to pass their classes, it appears to us that education isn't working. Many schools counteract this by simply lowering the grading standards in undergraduate classes, making it easier for these people to pass, get a diploma for general education, and then leave to get a job and pay off their loans. Thus we don't see a change in the grades and low-skill workers get to re-enter the job market. But making the problem transparent doesn't fix it -- technology is growing exponentially, and we can't simply repeat the process of sending these people that are no longer qualified to work back to college because we can't expect that a majority of them are going to get passed through each time, even with a grading curve. Moreover, the population of unskilled workers will be positively correlated to the exponential improvement in technology, so more and more people are being sent to college each time the patch is applied.

You have a pretty idealistic view of teachers. Have you heard of bloom 2 sigma problem? This problem refers to an educational phenomenon observed by educational psychologist Benjamin Bloom and initially reported in 1984 in the journal "Educational Researcher". Bloom found that the average
student tutored one-to-one using mastery learning techniques performed two standard
deviations better than students who learn via conventional instructional methods--that is,
"the average tutored student was above 98% of the students in the control class".

You can't reach that via conventional teaching methods, only now with iPads and iphones is it truly possible to have a mentor-protégé system on a wide scale. And one day the technology will be good enough. There will be an interactive, engaging app for every single subject and because its personalised students will perform much better they do in a classroom.

At least that's the theory. But it's a fallacy to think that since earlier technology failed to revolutionise education its proof that tablets, smart phones,etc. will also fail to do so. On the contrary I think we're witnessing the beginning of the edu revolution, which YouTube is a part of.

I recommend you look at traditional Jewish teaching methods. They include:
* Focus on how to learn rather than on content - Children study Jewish legal opinions in order to develop skills for reasoning.
* Freedom of movement in study - Children are encouraged to stand, sit or pace while they are learning
* Active learning - Children talk, sing, argue and even raise their voices while they are learning
* Learning with a partner - Much of the learning is done with a peer so that the children have an opportunity to explain and refute positions as they go
* Connecting it to the heart - Children are encouraged to be passionate about their learning
* Preparation for any field - Once children have the self-confidence and reasoning skills, they are able to study any other field with high success in a short period of time
For example, the Israel Defense Force (IDF) opened a track for traditionally trained students to participate in their most advanced cyber-security unit. The students required a few months of ramp-up studies, because most of them had not been exposed to computers before, but they are some of the most successful soldiers in the elite unit.

I think that what could actually revolutionize education is being able to have teachers who are great at leading classes without them also needing to understand the content particularly well. Currently, teachers need to both be great at teaching and know their subject really well, and that combination is much rarer than just being great at teaching. That means many more possible great teachers, and a much higher quality of the information that students learn. (There's a big time gap between when some knowledge is discovered and when effective high-school teachers start teaching it.) Outcomes are limited by the product of the quality of the instruction and the quality of the information, and being able to optimize the two dimensions separately, rather than the teacher's time being split between presentation skills and material development, could have an enormous impact.

The other thing that might be revolutionary is being able to form a class online, such that students can be in a Skype chat with their class, instead of not having a class available at all. There could certainly be a revolution in terms of the portion of children who can participate interactively with a teacher and peers who are learning the same material. If education happens in a small group setting, a revolution in education would require a revolution in small group communication. You listed a lot of technologies that didn't do anything for that, but Twitch (for example) is all about a moderator leading a small group of participants who interact live with each other and the moderator despite not being in the same room. Certainly, we haven't got any new technologies that are as good as the best classroom, but we've now got technologies that are better than many classrooms. That actually could revolutionize education, in the sense of giving the general public access to benefits formerly only available to the elite.

I would broaden what you're getting at to say what really would revolutionize education is evidence-based pedagogy.  As a teacher, education today seems to me to be similar to medicine of 100 years ago.  There's some training, and some reference material, and even some scientific discussion, but the vast majority of what a teacher does on a daily basis is driven primarily by experience of what works and what doesn't.  Contrast this to a doctor today, who relies on a vast body of medical research on everything from diagnostic criteria to interventions.  

Medicine was not always like that.  In the turn of the 20th century, doctors went to medical school and learned anatomy, they exchanged ideas for treatments, and some of the treatments had even been rigorously tested.  However the factor that completely revolutionized medicine was the idea that every treatment, diagnostic test, procedure, or approach had to be subjected to rigorous examination in controlled experiments.  It was not cheap to do that (the NIH has now far more money going to medical research than the NSF has going to all other areas of science, for example), but it made scientific investigation of medicine expected.  

We need the same evidence-based pedagogy.  Instead of piecemeal research of things that a professor might think is interesting to look at, research should be a standard and daily part of determining courses of action.  This comes with a price, but the benefits to society probably outpace even the benefits in medicine.  Evidence-based pedagogy would be a true revolution in education.

Through personal experience, I believe that the main problem with learning is the way it's structured.  While things like basic mathematics are more apt to a linear education curve, things like world history and science aren't. 

Starting with learning about a cell and progressing to an ecosystem, a progression that I was given in school, didn't interest me as much as my own experiences learning about biology on my own. 

Learning how a bacterium can help to break down the cells of an animal that has died as it's nutrients are redistributed amongst the various plants and animals in the surrounding area was a springboard for me to learn about the various types of bacterium in an environment, how plants absorb and utilize water and minerals to grow, the different types of cell structures between plants, animals, bacterium, and viruses, how viruses infect other organisms.... 

All of those different areas of biology were made relevant and interesting to me because I saw an animal caucus rotting on the side of a bike path when I was younger.  While I did learn about each of those things in school over time, it was the initial interest in how they all interacted on that occasion that made me pay attention in class and do my own research on the different subjects.

The dessicated remains also lead to my interest in ancient Egyptian mummies.  That lead me to learn about various other types of mummies around the world, such as the peat mummies of Europe and the frozen mummies of the Inca.

Each experience lead me to become interested in something else, prompting me to learn about new things each time.  My interests allowed me to be far more educated on areas of study such as ancient Egypt and mummies in general compared to my classmates.

What I am basically trying to explain is that if you can encourage and assist in a child's interests about something that would otherwise be considered mundane, it can help them to expand that interest into knowledge that will more than likely be beneficial to them in the future some how.  It will at the very least encourage them to want to expand their knowledge beyond whatever limitations a standard educational system might have to deal with.

America's educational system is one of my pet peeves. So much emphasis on grading and metrics, to the extent that students wind up "playing the game" (learning for the grade) as opposed to learning for the sake of enjoyment, or knowledge, or increased capability.

And the fault goes all the way up the ladder, to the people who decide what "standards of learning" look like. We have all this standardization that is supposed to turn into something demonstrable ("show that this student has retained something"), so that we can churn people through systems of paperwork, but we lose half the authenticity in the process.

I mean, I can easily recall the classes I took in college where I would find myself too bogged down in the looming threat of tests and quizzes to actually give the material proper analysis and time to digest. Too many would become a game of sneaking in just enough rote memorization to get by.

It wasn't all bad though; some classes engaged me and managed to find a merging of "space to learn" and "metric-based projects," but these were usually run by ballsy teachers in higher-level classes (where rote demonstration of basics is less enforced).

I'm just scratching the surface on what aggravates me about the educational system, but the general idea is: The system works against itself. Many teachers just want students to learn, but they are trapped within absurdly limiting standards, while students are expected to juggle 4-6 different subjects per semester and somehow retain valuable principles from all them. But ultimately, instead of being rewarded for a love to learn or interest in a subject, students' progress is only acknowledged in the form of a grade that will follow them for the rest of their lives (more so, depending on what profession they go into).

And then the teachers are left to somehow work through that muck and jump through a series of hoops to create an environment that inspires lasting learning.

Honestly, I think traditional teachers are one of the most under-appreciated and underestimated (in terms of difficulty) professions that exists - if only because of the games that they have to play with the system just to get to the part where they can guide students through a strong learning experience.

When I was studying education at CQU Rockhampton, about eight years ago now, they introduced the idea of the "Learning Manager" to me.  The lecturers didn't like the word "teacher" because it implied the old method of chalking and talking, while a "Learning Manager" was supposed to have a two way engagement with the students.  In that regard, I don't think Youtube will revolutionise education, because the interaction is still almost entirely one way.  I can't ask a question about the subject material of a video.  Sure, there's a comments section, but imagine a classroom where (let's take the current view count) 14,401 students were listening to one teacher, and even just a third of them had a question.  The teacher would never get to all of them, even if there were only ten unique questions between them.  People usually discuss the content of a video in the comments section, but if I wanted to know more from people with dubious qualification to answer, I'd be reading the Wikipedia article.

I think the "Digital Aristotle" idea is a great step, but I think, instead of having preprogrammed courses, or a course generator based on some arbitrary idea of skill required for subject matter, it needs to have a very strong artificial intelligence.  Something which can parse information, understand it as related, and provide that two way educational experience.

Another impacting factor on learning outcomes is the various types of learners.  Some people do do better with audiovisial media, while other people could digest an entire textbook.  If you teach them with the wrong method, their information retention will be much less successful.  Solely with videos, the pace is still problematic for most of the audience.  The only people likely to maintain viewership are the ones for whom the pace is perfect.  People who think you're going too slow will move on, and people who think you're going too fast will give up, so educational video makers on Youtube suffer from a bit of selection bias when it comes to engagement.  Youtube can only ever really sovle the pace problem one way:  saturation.  There will eventually be enough educational video makers that there will be someone working at the right pace for any learner.  The problem, then, is finding them.

The bigger issue I have here is that it says nothing about transferring the agency of learning to the learner. All sticky learning is intrinsically motivated. We may "learn" something for a short time for a transient reward (a passing test score, for example.) But what sticks with us is the stuff we wanted to learn more about, after the class has ended. 

Here's what will transform education: Giving learners a greater freedom to learn. Moving the focus of schooling away from curriculum and knowledge that we decide is important (which is now everywhere) to the process of learning. Moving our emphasis away from student as product toward student as ongoing, master learner who can make use of everything that's now available to her. 

The huge promise of technology will only be realized when we situate our discussions around it in the context of learning and increasing student autonomy and agency. As long as we see oursleves as the arbiters of what will be learned, when and how, the "revolution" will never take place.

I think this video fails on one key element: It's narrow definition of education. You seem to be looking at education strictly from a traditional classroom+ teacher model. That is but a narrow sliver of a fragment of a view of what education is or can be. Education has been revolutionized in the last 30 years... by the Internet. It has put such a wealth of information at easy access that it has completely altered the very types of knowledge that are required to thrive in society. Strict memorization and rote calculation are on the decline, whereas the ability to craft a query properly, or be able to read a piece of information critically have become orders of magnitude more important.
Additionally, the social environment has been vastly altered as well. We now have gone back to being a society that communicates primarily via the written word. Writing skills, particularly persuasive writing skills, have swelled in importance. We have developed an entirely new method of communication to help transmit emotional context along with our words (emoji). As these skills have become more important, so too have our reading skills, both in speed and in comprehension.

The key element of education that I think you miss in your critique is that, at its heart, education is personal. What works for student A doesn't work for student B, and student C will progress at a different rate than either or the other two. The old one-room schoolhouse was a much more ideal environment. There, each student progressed at their own pace, under the guidance of the teacher. It was, in many respects, a much less social environment than today's classroom, but the mixing of different abilities allowed for differing rates of learning. Now, with the "grade level" model, students are either restrained from progress in topics that they excel in, or rushed through topics that they struggle with, just because overall they fit within a fuzzy range of "normal" for an extremely wide age and development range, particularly in elementary school.
This too is where the digital age shows promise. Through the use of rudimentary AIs and evaluation protocols, it will become easier to craft an individualized education plan for each student, one that can target both the appropriate material to challenge the student, and the teaching modality that best works for that individual. You can still involve teachers, but the classrooms will become more virtual, as similar students are gathered from a much wider geographic area, and paired with a teacher that can work best with that particular group of children.

I totally disagree about environment being irrelevant, Derek.  I was a mediocre student in high school.  I learned material without trying, but I didn't put any effort into anything.  Solid B student, didn't really care.  I dropped out halfway through and went to an early college.  It is a place designed for 14-16 year olds who never completed high school.  It was challenging, rated as the number 1 undergraduate program in the US at the time (and I believe still top 3 or 5).  While I was there I saw a huge number of mediocre students with frankly average intelligence do pretty amazing things.  Kids who showed up without a firm understanding of trigonometry who were taking graduate level analysis courses two years later.  Kids who didn't even know what java was programming some pretty awesome AI within a few semesters.  I saw 19 year olds graduating from a top college and going on to Oxford, Harvard, Yale, et cetera for graduate degrees.  I saw a 15 year old who, during her sophomore year, launched her own start up and by her senior year was a multimillionaire.  Amazing things coming from people who didn't start out as anything special.  There were otherwise average kids.

So what is the difference?  Environment.  When you're put into a situation where you're expected to excel, you excel.  When you're told you're going to understand this material, get great grades, and go on to finish your graduate degree at Oxford or Yale, you do so.  I saw kids who weren't particularly good at chemistry, who studied 6 hours a day, 4 days a week, to pass Orgo II with an A so they would qualify for their graduate degree the following semester.  I was one of them.  Of the 10 kids I took that course with, 3 of them are published chemists, 3 are finishing medical school from top med schools, 1 is a harvard trained lawyer, and 1 is working towards a neuroscience Phd in ucla.  And, even more amazing, a bunch of those kids showed up unable to speak English fluently.

Environment means absolutely everything.  If you want children to succeed, you put them in an environment where success isn't an option, it is expected.  Where hard work isn't an option, it is required.  Kids will rise to the standards you set for them.

I think this will revolutionize education!!:

No but seriously :) In my opinion, our efforts to advance in education are focusing on the misleading part of the equation; the equation between first the teacher (person, who has the information), second the student (person, who is going to receive the information) and third the way of transmitting that info.

What we have been focused on this equation mostly (as it was also presented in the video) is the way we transfer this information. We will never find a single perfect and certain way to deliver information to individuals. Because the very dynamics of this transfer is changing with every single combination of the teacher and the student. A teacher may explain a certain topic to a student and make him learn.  But when it comes to doing the same thing to another one, efficiency is not guaranteed to be as the same level as it was with the previous student.

This is because every person perceives the world in a slightly different way (literally :) ). Due to this infinitesimal difference, we tend to think that there must be a way to deliver information in a single perfect way, since we observe an average level for student's understanding of the class. This small difference fades away with the increased number of students. But, as probability dictates, although the average does not tend to change a lot, chance to find students with very different efficiency of understanding increases as well. I mean, given enough number of them, there will always be a student in the class, who didn't understand almost anything at all after the lecture!

Because you cannot reach to each student in the same way! Some people learn through reading, some learn through visual elements, some through actively participating (like experiments and stuff) and some learn in a very different way. Of course our brains are capable of handling problems and that's why it is not creating a crucial issue to try to educate a child, who let's say learns through visual elements, by making him/her reading the material. What happens at most is that child will be diagnosed with inability to concentrate, hyperactivity or something similar.

But again, we are focusing on the wrong factor. The fact we need to realize is every student requires a different way of education. Even not for every, at least we need to be able to classify group of students, who show similar behavior to a certain way of education, and then divide them accordingly to increase the efficiency of the way we transfer information.

For example, I never like to read material. I've chosen engineering because of this, and still cannot tolerate long paragraphs for more than 5 minutes. I'm easily distracted when it comes to reading. However, when it comes to watching videos on YouTube, like Veritasium, Vsauce, MinutePhysics, or any other educational video; I am attracted to that info much more quickly. And that is not only valid for YouTube. Even some engineering courses I have, sometimes use animations and etc. and I hardly get bored, or distracted. And I actually understand much better and efficiently compared to spending my time on reading only 3 pages information for like 1 hour...

On the other hand, some of my friends claim that they learn better through reading. And they tend to get better grades in classes that involves articles, readings etc.

Me and my friends, we all took same courses, of course thought in only one way. Sometimes I get better grades in some of them, sometimes they do, wonder why?

Briefly, what I believe is, problem is not the medium, in which we transfer the information. Problem is we are constantly trying to impose the same-single way (the way, with which we think we revolutionize the education) to all of the students. With every "revolutionizing" way, we observe some issues, and develop a way to overcome that issue. But then again we observe more issues, just after we thought that we made it perfect by fixing that previous one. However, what we do is, we only address to only a group of students.

I'm very much against all of this hugely wasteful spending on technology by schools.  It's no longer about finding the best way to teach our children, it's about which politician or school official has a vested interest in whichever company they decide to purchase the above-normal-price electronics from.  Schools also want to keep their technology budgets, so it's a "use it or lose it" mentality of buying dozens or hundreds of brand new machines every couple of years just to run Word.  And what has it gotten us, really?  America's educational system is pretty pathetic, and that's not changing, despite the budgets making bigger and bigger holes for technology. 

I was in the work-study program in school, actually fixing computers since the tech staff was composed of roughly three people, most of which incompetent and/or hired through nepotism, for a school of over a thousand students.  So I was privy to much of what went on.  The computers became infested with malware/viruses daily, or messed up in general by students either maliciously or accidentally, and many of the machines end up piled in a back room somewhere, never to be fixed.  And when they buy new ones, the "old" ones end up piled in a similar back room, unable to be given or sold to students if one of them might want one, but left to rot until all of the bureaucracy finally decides to send them to another school with a lesser budget, where half of them will sit in yet another room until someone can prepare them for use.

As for the educational benefits, they'll never replace a book.  As much as I love technology, and as much as I loved those times when we actually had excuses to use a computer in school (Apple II's in elementary, "top of the line" 486s by high school), I still acknowledge that there's something lost when consuming content from a screen.  Your brain is designed to remember physical locations, smells, touch, textures, etc.  I can very clearly remember being able to recall the answer to test questions sometimes based on where that answer was physically at on the page of a textbook.  This is something that can never be replicated by technology, maybe until we have something like e-ink books.  Otherwise, it's a stationary piece of technology, where your eyes never move from that one small area, forcing you to retain just the raw information without any other memory triggers commonly used by our brains.  I've been using computers for decades now, and I can tell you that retaining information from this screen is never the same as doing it from physical content.

I think we're harming children, and plenty of studies have backed up the negative affects of technology on young people.  But we're going to keep right on doing it, because people who make money from this are good at convincing you we need it, and that we need the most expensive ones they can find (like iPads) at that.

I find it odd that you kind of gloss over the "interaction" aspect and focus on the "social".  It is the interaction that facilitates learning and the problems with all of the aforementioned methods that would "revolutionize" education is that they did not take that into account.  You do not need a classroom or a teacher for a student to be engaged in what they are doing.  Programming, carpentry, music...  Yes critique in a social situation helps with a students understanding of the things they are learning, as well as giving them the ability to relate to others experiences.  But the core method of learning most skills is by actually DOING whatever it is you are trying to learn.

If you want a revolution in education, you need to increase the context of the information being presented.  You need to allow the student to actually USE what they are being taught in a practical manner.  I am not saying teachers are unnecessary, but implying that learning needs to be a social process ignores the fundamental methods by which people obtain new skills.
